article: In my second year of high school, the class was to run the mile. I will always _ that day because due to the _ from medical operation on my _ , for two years I had not worn shorts. I was afraid of being laughed at. Yet that day, it didn't _ . I was ready _ , heart and mind. I had no sooner got to the starting line than I heard the loud _ . "How ugly!" I blocked it out. Then the coach shouted, "Ready. Go!" I jetted out of there like a _ , faster than anyone else for the first 20 feet. I knew _ about speed then, but it was OK because I was _ to finish first. As I started the third lap , only a few of my classmates were left on the track, and I began limping . By the time I hit the fourth lap, I was _ . Then it hit me. I realized that nobody had given up . Everyone had already finished, _ . As I ran that last lap, I cried. _ 12 minutes 42 seconds after starting I crossed the finish line. I _ to the ground and shed oceans. Suddenly my coach ran up to me and picked me up, saying, "You did it. Manuel! Son, you FINISHED!" He looked at me _ in the eyes, waving a piece of paper in his hand. It was my _ for the day, which I had given to him before class. He read it _ to everyone. It simply said, "I, Manuel, will finish the mile run tomorrow, come what may." My heart _ with a smile on my face. My classmates cheered. It was then that I _ winning isn't always finishing first. Sometimes winning is just finishing.
